Based on my search results, I can provide detailed information about "The Old Man and the Sea" related to your query:

## Word Count and Novella Length

The manuscript for "The Old Man and the Sea" was 26,531 words long, which places it firmly in the novella category at approximately 26,000 words. Novellas typically contain around 20,000 to 30,000 words, generally between 17,500 and 40,000 words.

## Life Magazine Publication and Sales Records

Life magazine published the full novella in its September 1, 1952 issue. This was a significant publishing event, as Hemingway was delighted when Leland Hayward secured the publication of the entire novella in one issue of Life magazine.

The sales figures were record-breaking:
- The magazine sold a record 5.3 million copies in two days
- The Life magazine edition sold more than 5 million copies in a week

## Publication Success

The novella achieved remarkable commercial and critical success:
- Scribner's released their first edition a week later on September 8th
- Advanced sales of Scribner's edition in America and Jonathan Cape's edition in Britain reached a total of 70,000
- It remained on the New York Times bestseller list for six months (twenty-six weeks) and was translated into nine languages by the end of 1952
- In 1953, it received the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction, and it was the only work explicitly mentioned when Hemingway was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1954

The publication in Life magazine was particularly notable because Life Magazine published the novella in its entirety, recognizing that Hemingway, the most influential writer of 20th century American literature and then a world-wide celebrity, had delivered a long-awaited masterful story.
